cards.front:
The extremity lift would not be appropriate to use on a patient:

(See Nonurgent Moves)
cards.back: with a deformed humerus.

cards.front:
Which of the following statements regarding patient weight distribution is correct?

(See Principles of Safe Lifting and Carrying)
cards.back: The majority of a horizontal patient’s weight is in the torso.

cards.front:
You should not attempt to lift a patient who weighs more than 250 pounds with fewer than _______ rescuers, regardless of individual strength.

(See Principles of Safe Lifting and Carrying)
cards.back: four

cards.front:
To minimize the risk of injuring yourself when lifting or moving a patient, you should:

(See Principles of Safe Lifting and Carrying)
cards.back: keep the weight as close to your body as possible.

cards.front:
The first rule of safe lifting is to:

(See Body Mechanics)
cards.back: keep your back in a straight, vertical position.

cards.front:
The most appropriate carrying device to use when moving a patient across rough or uneven terrain is the:

(See Additional Patient-Moving Equipment)
cards.back: basket stretcher.

cards.front:
The _________ is both the mechanical weight-bearing base of the spinal column and the fused central posterior section of the pelvic girdle.

(See Body Mechanics)
cards.back: sacrum

cards.front:
When using a body drag to pull a patient who is on the ground, you should:

(See Principles of Safe Reaching and Pulling)
cards.back: kneel to minimize the distance that you will have to lean over.

cards.front:
Which of the following most accurately describes the correct position of the EMTs who are executing the diamond carry technique?

(See Principles of Safe Lifting and Carrying)
cards.back: One at the head, one at the feet, and one on each side of the patient’s torso

cards.front:
It is essential that you ____________ your equipment to prevent the spread of disease.

(See Additional Patient-Moving Equipment)
cards.back: decontaminate

cards.front:
When the shoulder girdle is aligned over the pelvis during lifting:

(See Body Mechanics)
cards.back: the weight is exerted straight down the vertebrae.

cards.front:
The direct carry is used to transfer a patient:

(See Nonurgent Moves)
cards.back: from a bed to the ambulance stretcher.

cards.front:
The most serious consequence of a poorly planned or rushed patient move is:

(See Nonurgent Moves)
cards.back: injury to you or your patient.

cards.front:
When carrying a patient up or down stairs, you should avoid:

(See The Wheeled Ambulance Stretcher)
cards.back: using a wheeled stretcher whenever possible.

cards.front:
In contrast to typical wheeled ambulance stretchers, features of a bariatric stretcher include:

(See Additional Patient-Moving Equipment)
cards.back: increased stability from a wider wheelbase.

cards.front:
Which of the following situations would require an urgent patient move?

(See Urgent Moves)
cards.back: Semiconscious patient with shallow respirations and signs of shock

cards.front:
When a person is standing upright, the weight of anything being lifted and carried in the hands is first reflected onto the:

(See Body Mechanics)
cards.back: shoulder girdle.

cards.front:
After applying medical restraints to a combative patient, you should:

(See Patient Positioning)
cards.back: remove them only after hospital personnel have requested you to do so.

cards.front:
Which of the following statements regarding the scoop stretcher is not correct?

(See Nonurgent Moves)
cards.back: A scoop stretcher will provide adequate immobilization of a patient’s spinal column.

cards.front:
Which is the most appropriate method to use when moving a patient from his or her bed to a wheeled stretcher?

(See Nonurgent Moves)
cards.back: Draw sheet method
